subject: Comparing arrays in JUnit 4
msgSnippet: Using the new array compare method this test case fails: @Test public void testArrayCompare() { int[] a = {1, 2, 3}; int[] b = {1, 2, 3}; assertEquals(a, b); }
messageBody:
Using the new array compare method this test case fails:

@Test public void testArrayCompare() {
int[] a = {1, 2, 3};
int[] b = {1, 2, 3};
assertEquals(a, b);

}

However this one succeeds:

@Test public void testArrayCompare() {
Object[] a = {1, 2, 3};
Object[] b = {1, 2, 3};
assertEquals(a, b);

}

This is a compile time error:

@Test public void testArrayCompare() {
int[] a = {1, 2, 3};
int[] b = {1, 2, 3};
assertEquals((Object[]) a, (Object[]) b);

}


This test case also fails:

@Test public void testArrayCompare() {
int[] a = {1, 2, 3};
int[] b = {1, 2, 3};
assertEquals((Object) a, (Object) b);

}


Short of adding 162 different methods to compare each and every possible
combination of arrays (something I would not rule out but it certainly
wouldn't be my first choice) does anyone see a reasonable way to use
Java 5 autoboxing to allow arrays of primitive data types to be compared?
